body_html:
The application-specific fields are stored on the user record so that they always "belong" to a certain student. The knack with the application draft is: it's not too easy to be sure who's student0 and who's student1 when a student accesses the application draft form. The ApplicationDraft#students method attempts to make this deterministic, but I don't know what happens if a student changes their pair in the existing team – were the studentX_* fields stored on the ApplicationDraft record, this could result in possible privacy disclosure.

It's a difficult topic – I hope I could shine at least some light onto this? 🔦

If anyone has a good solution for not storing the application specific data on the user record, please speak up 😄 For the time being I think it's best to DRY the form fields w/o touching the database columns.

body:
The application-specific fields are stored on the user record so that they always "belong" to a certain student. The knack with the application draft is: it's not too easy to be sure who's `student0` and who's `student1` when a student accesses the application draft form. The `ApplicationDraft#students` method attempts to make this deterministic, but I don't know what happens if a student changes their pair in the existing team – were the `studentX_*` fields stored on the ApplicationDraft record, this could result in possible privacy disclosure.

It's a difficult topic – I hope I could shine at least some light onto this? 🔦 

If anyone has a good solution for not storing the application specific data on the user record, please speak up 😄 For the time being I think it's best to DRY the form fields w/o touching the database columns.
